BE

The latest raft of Chinese import stats confirm three things. Firstly, that low prices will entice Chinese buyers out of hiding. Most of the key commodities were up strongly year on year, with oil, copper, platinum and iron ore imports up 8%, 12%, 47% and 22% respectively. Secondly, that ores are preferred over refined metals, with copper concentrate imports up 11% and zinc concentrate up 60%. In contrast, copper and zinc metal imports are down. Thirdly, excess capacity will continue to be exported especially if the arbitrage is favourable. Steel and aluminium semi’s were both up in the month. It is too early to take the strong imports as a sign of demand recovery in our view.

PM

This is what that clairvoyant fjp was alluding to yesterday

BE

Aluminium semi’s exports rebound and steel remains robust

Exports of steel and aluminium are up c.22% and c.14% year to date respectively reinforcing our view that in both industries, Chinese overcapacity is being exported. Aluminium semi’s export rebounded after subdued exports in last three months. Aluminium exports (447kt) increased significantly by 35% month on month, which seems to suggest that October’s exports; the lowest in 20 months, were simply a blip. The rise in aluminium exports is however entirely consistent with the increase in the semi’s export arbitrage which is now at USD224/t. Steel exports were essentially flat month on month, with no signs of a let up. We expect further anti dumping / export taxes to be imposed on China over the course of 2016. So far there is no evidence that this is having a material impact on the overall export level.

11:06 am
BE

Steel making materials remain weak

Chinese iron ore imports have followed the typical “saw-tooth” pattern we have come to expect; two months up, two months down. November imports were up 9% month on month and up 22% year on year. Year to date imports are now flat (+1.3%). This trend is consistent with weak domestic steel demand and a loss in market share of the domestic iron ore producers. Likewise Coking coal imports, whilst rebounding slightly in the month remain weak, down 21% year to date. There is a glimmer of hope pointing to slowing domestic output, with Coke exports down 3% year to date.

Copper imports remain steady; a strong rebound in copper concentrate

The demand for copper cathodes has been relatively weak in 2015, with imports down 3% year to date, despite the November level of 460kt up 10% month on month. Liekwise scrap imports remain weak, down 7% year to date However, this “shortfall” has been compensated by imports of concentrate , with imports rebounding strongly in November, up 25% year on year, pushing the year to date figure to 11%. We estimate Chinese apparent copper demand is up 2.8% year to date for 2015. The trade flows around nickel continues to be more supportive. Although refined nickel imports are down 18% month on month, November’s import level is still robust at 27.6kt. Parts of these imports are however, simply a reallocation of stocks back to Ore imports from the Philippines are down c.4% year to date. Part of the monthly decline is however due to weak demand and hence ore weak pricing not being attractive enough to export, and partly due to seasonality. We do continue to question the sustainability of Philippine ore supply at current pricing levels.

BE

BE

GAME Digital has warned of materially softer revenue run rates through its all-important Q2, resulting in Ebitda expectations for H1 of £30m, down £13m YoY, and driving material downgrades.

GAME reported significant UK video games market declines (market down 13.5% in the 21 weeks ended December 19th). This was partly driven by ultra low-margin console sales. But content sales also disappointed, due to an accelerated decline in previous generation format sales (Xbox360/PS3), which were -57% YoY. GAME has also seen lower than expected Xbox One/PS4 content sales (particularly second tier titles and back list). Importantly, it has held market share (i.e. this is not a GAME-specific issue). But GAME points to "lower year on year high street and shopping centre footfalls", particularly in recent weeks, pointing to a more rapid transition from traditional retail sales to online.

This has not been a Black Friday related issue (Black Friday gross profits were up marginally YoY). And the group has seen a robust performance from its Spanish division, and also from GAMEtronics (+92% YoY). But group revenues (transactional value) are down 6.7% YTD, and it expects H1 Ebitda of £30m, down £13m or -30%.

11:20 am
BE

Yeah, Widdly thing.

BE

Impact on the Canaccord Genuity view

GAME is just heading into its peak sales period, so this is a particularly disappointing update. Visibility remains limited, but it is now extrapolating recent weak trends. And prospects for H2 remain muted - we project the group to be marginally profitable. Given the extent of H1 weakness, we downgrade FY16F PBT (norm) from £38.9m/18.1p to £21.7m/10.1p, a 44% downgrade. At this stage we maintain a flat dividend at 14.7p; but there is clearly some risk of a dividend cut (despite £47m of projected FY16F year end net cash), given that it is uncovered by projected Earnings in FY16F and FY17F. Our FY17F PBT (norm) forecast comes down from £41.2m/19.3p to £24.4m/11.4p.

Valuation

On our revised forecasts, GAME is currently trading on a calendarised 2016 PER of 19.7x and 9.2x EV/Ebitda, albeit backed by a projected 7.0% dividend yield. Given the extent of downgrades we expect to see short term weakness in the shares. The company offers exposure to significant structural growth in the eSports market, through Multiplay, but short-term investor focus will remain on the outlook for Retail. We downgrade our TP from 270p to 183p to reflect the downgrades - this would represent a 2016 calendarised EV/Ebitda of 8.0x (a 10% discount to Dixons Carphone), a PER of 17.0x and an 8.0% dividend yield. We move our recommendation from Buy to HOLD.

Share performance catalyst

Post-Christmas trading update (expected to be in the week beginning January 11th), performance of key new releases, dividend payout, hardware releases (i.e. Nintendo NX and Virtual Reality) and expansion of eSports.

BE

And Liberum.

11:21 am
BE

UK sales have fallen off sharply in the past few weeks at the most critical time of year for GAME. General weakness has been exacerbated by very rapidly slowing sales in old format content, down 57% in the UK, and while sales of new generation content remained strong these were not enough to offset the decline. The Spanish market remains strong with sales up 8%. While a decline in old format sales was expected the scale has surprised the company while the importance of Christmas trading has hugely magnified the issue. We cut our FY EPS forecasts by 60%, 2017e by 42% and 2018e by 30%. There is no updated guidance on the dividend, but we note that current year cover is just 0.5x. We place our rating and TP under review.
UK slowdown
While GAME traded well through Black Friday, December has seen very poor sales, in the UK, in old format games. Total sales in the video games market were down 13.5% on the prior year with GAME down 11.4%. The faster than expected decline in old format sales was not offset by the anticipated switch to new generation content. UK console sales declined by 28% but given the very low achieved gross margins this was immaterial in gross profit terms.
Footfall is down in stores, as is the case with retail across the UK with shopping centres reporting a decline in customer numbers, but while there is increased participation online we do not believe that this is an issue of disintermediation. The company has maintained its share of retail digital downloads, and while there is no publicly available data on the total download market we understand, anecdotally, that there has been no material move towards direct downloads from publishers.
The slow down in old format content sales has not affected the Spanish market where GTV is up 8.1%, albeit with gross profit up 5.5%.

BE

Forecast cuts
We have cut our FY EPS forecast by 60%, and outer years by 42% and 30%. The company has guided towards H1 EBITDA of £30m although at this stage we estimate £27.3m, with just £0.4m EBITDA in H2. Our forecasts are based on a 5.5% decline in FY sales and an 80 bps decline in FY gross margin.
Dividend
While the company has not updated guidance on the dividend we note that cover has fallen to 0.5x this year, and only reaches parity by 2018e. The balance sheet remains cash positive, albeit we now forecast a year end net cash position of £48.7m, from our previous estimate of £65.2m. While the company still intends to update the market on Christmas sales in mid January we think that a decision on the dividend may be defered until the interim results in March when the company has a much clearer idea of FY profits.

BE

The conclusion -- as you'd expect, they're an arb -- is that the deal goes through. But the working involved in reaching that conclusion is heroic.

11:30 am
PM

(there. gif gone. sorry)

BE

The current spread suggests that the market remains paranoid about risk of Royal Dutch Shell failing to win support from 50% of voting shareholders. Even ignoring our own first-hand feedback from this shareholder base (which makes us comfortable with the dynamics of the vote) – pure statistical analysis suggests that this risk should be modelled as a low probability event. We currently have break prices for BG and RDS of 704 and 1703 respectively, suggesting that the market is ascribing a 73% chance of the transaction completing. Clearly stating the obvious, but whichever way we approach the concept of shareholder risk, the chances of a successful deal are materially higher than the market currently models.

BE

And in terms of what the data say ….

11:31 am
BE

· 70% (18 of the top 26) of shareholders have increased their weighting in BG relative to Shell since the announcement of the deal.

· The relative weight of BG to RDS in the FTSE has gone from 22% to 33% over the life of the deal and 9 of these top 26 shareholders (35%) have upped their weight in BG in excess of this.

· The RDS votes owned by those disclosed holders who have increased their exposure to BG amount to 34%. Those that have increased in excess of the index reweighting amount to 5.7% of RDS votes.

· Modelling a 65% turnout at the forthcoming RDS EGM would suggest a voting power of 68% and 11.4% respectively of these groups.

· We can look at the behaviour of the top 5 RDS shareholders: Capital we discuss below, but Blackrock, as the largest RDS holder have increased their BG position (# shares) by 2%, and in RDS by an identical percentage. Legal & General have decreased BG by 1% and decreased RDS by 0.3%. State Street have decreased BG by 10% and RDS by 6.5%. Aberdeen have decreased their BG holding by 10% and decreased their RDS position by 8%.

· Of those that have NOT increased their BG weighting, we only have Qatar (1.36% of RDS, and the press lead us to believe are supportive), T Rowe (81bps), Capital (3.87%), Wellington (17bps) and Threadneedle (94bps). Summing these entities gives 7.15% of the Shell register, obviously heavily skewed towards Capital and Qatar. Threadneedle have added materially to RDS positions since the start of the transaction.

BE

Contact Olivetree directly for the full spreadsheet.

BE

n our view, the combination of prolonged unseasonable weather, a still very promotional US market and further slowdown in Asia is set to take the shine off TED's momentum in the near future. While still outperforming peers, we expect TED's shares to pause for a breather at peak multiples having rerated by c20% in the past year. We up our target by 6% to 3400p but downgrade to Hold.

Forecasts trimmed, now more in line with consensus. The external factors flagged by TED which led to a slowdown in retail sales growth to lsd% in Q3 (ex-fx and shift in timing of promotions) was the most moderate recorded in recent years. Given prolonged unseasonable warm weather across all core geographies into late December, and the weakness/uncertainties in a still promotional US market, we believe TED's impressive momentum is less supported in the near term. We trim our sales forecast marginally and model -50bps retail gross margin in H2 15/16 (from -15bps) to factor in some weather-driven promotions and mix shift to post-Christmas discounted sales. This brings our FY 15/16E PBT to £58.6m (from £59.5m), in line with company-compiled consensus. Our outer year forecasts are also lowered slightly to include the c£1m dilution to PBT from TED's recent acquisition of its London HQ.

BE

We continue to be fans of the Ted Baker brand, its quirkiness, a clear USP, nimble business model and international expansion potential. Having impressively outperformed its LT targets of c.mid-teens% growth in retail sales/earnings for 3 consecutive years, we see near term headwinds in the US (c20% of group sales) to take the shine off TED's exceptional run and normalise closer towards its LT ambition (which remains a much enviable growth profile). We still expect gradual EBIT margin expansion of 10-20bps pa in the MT as TED leverages its logistics and digital investments.

A breather for now as we expect TED's shares to pause near term following a rerating streak (20% L12M, 40% L24M, 60% L36M). Our target increases by 6% to 3400p and we value TED on c26x 2017 PE (from 28x 2016 PE previously) which remains a premium to peers at c24x. This translates into 1.4x TSR (3YR EPS CAGR c16% + c2% yield) though with greater than 10% upside, we downgrade to Hold.

Q3 GDP: SANTA DELIVERS THE UK A LUMP OF COAL FOR CHRISTMAS

11:52 am
PM

Berenberg

BE

K.

PM

The UK economy ends the year on a very sour note. Final GDP estimates for Q3 show that the economy expanded by just 0.4% qoq, down from the previous estimate of 0.5%. Large revisions were also made to the back data. In Q2 they show the economy expanded by just 0.5% qoq versus a previous estimate of 0.7%. Revised data show that in the first 3 quarters of 2015, the economy grew at an average annual rate of 2.3%, down 0.2ppt from the previous estimate. Furthermore, although the headline 2014 growth rate of 2.9% yoy remained unchanged, it had been revised down by 0.09ppt from 2.94% yoy to 2.85% yoy. These changes significantly alter the quarterly growth story for 2015. Rather than a weak first quarter, a strong second quarter and an ok third quarter, disappointingly, data now show that the economy has been growing below trend all year. For the final quarter, we look for a modest rebound to 0.6% qoq growth, supported by stronger than expected gains in employment in recent months.

11:52 am
PM

Only consumption held up against sweeping downward revisions. Driven by moderate real wage growth and a strong labour market, consumption grew by 0.9% qoq, versus a previous estimate of 0.8%. Quarterly growth rates of government spending (0.6%) and gross fixed capital formation (0.7%) softened against previous estimates, though this was in part due to moderate upward revisions in Q2. Strong sterling and weak global demand hit exports hard, declining by 0.3% qoq against previous estimates of 0.9% qoq growth. Luckily, imports grew by just 2.7% - much weaker than previously estimated (5.5%). However, weaker growth in imports has softened the impact on overall trade. Imports grew by just 2.7% - much weaker than previously estimated (5.5%).

PM

Heightened risks heading into 2016: From above-trend growth of 2.9% yoy in 2014 to 2.3% yoy based on the first three quarters of data for 2015, it is clear that the pace of expansion has eased considerably. Undoubtedly, weaker global growth due to the slowdown in China and the EM rout has been a significant drag on growth this year. However, thanks to strong domestic demand the UK has managed to stave off the worst of it. In 2016, these external risks will continue to hang over the UK. But a new domestic risk will come into play. That is, the risk of the UK leaving the EU. Whilst we assign only a 30% risk of a Brexit, disruptions in the run up to the vote and the potential risk of an exit pose the most significant downside risk to the outlook in 2016.

BE

And here's Dr Howard Archer, Chief European & UK Economist at IHS Economics & Country Risk.

11:53 am
BE

he current account deficit was stable at £17.5 billion (3.7% of GDP) in the third quarter of 2015 after narrowing markedly to this level in the second quarter from £23.3 billion (5.0% of GDP) in the first quarter of 2015 and a peak of £28.5 billion (6.2% of GDP) in the fourth quarter of 2014.

The current account deficit was stable in the third quarter despite a marked relapse in the total trade deficit. Specifically, the total trade deficit moved back out to £8.7 billion in the third quarter after narrowing sharply to £4.7 billion in the second quarter from £10.7 billion in the first quarter. UK exports of goods and services fell 2.2% quarter-on-quarter in the third quarter to £127.7 billion, which reversed the 2.1% quarter-on-quarter gain in the second quarter. Meanwhile, UK imports of goods and services edged up 0.9% quarter-on-quarter in the third quarter to £135.2 billion after dipping 2.4% quarter-on-quarter in the second quarter.

However, the renewed widening in the trade deficit in the third quarter was countered by a further narrowing in the shortfall in the UK’s net primary income account. This came down to £3.3 billion in the third quarter (the lowest shortfall since the second quarter of 2013) from £6.6 billion in the second quarter, £7.0 billion in the first quarter of 2015 and a record £11.5 billion in the fourth quarter of 2014. The third quarter reduction in the deficit on the primary income account was driven by a reduction from £6.0 billion to £3.1 billion in the net loss on investment income. This was the consequence of reduced foreign earnings on direct and portfolio investment in the UK, while UK earnings on investment abroad was essentially stable.

Nevertheless, this was the 12th deficit in 13 quarters on the UK’s net primary income balance (the exception being a modest surplus in the second quarter of 2013). This contrasts with the regular surpluses on the primary income account that the UK regularly saw up until the end of 2011. The UK’s recent appreciable shortfalls on its net primary income account significantly reflects the fact that UK earnings on direct investment abroad have been much reduced since 2011, which has been substantially influenced by the weakness of Eurozone economic activity. In addition, sterling’s strength has reduced the value of overseas investment earnings when translated into pounds.

It is of some relief that the UK current account deficit did not widen as expected in the third quarter. While the markets have so far taken a relatively relaxed view of the UK’s elevated current account deficit, it could become an increasing problem if the markets lose confidence in the UK economy for any reason. The Bank of England has indicated that it will be closely monitoring whether the forthcoming referendum affects the inward flow of foreign direct investment and portfolio investment that play a key role in financing the current account deficit.

One potential trigger for the markets losing confidence in the UK economy could be increasing uncertainty and concern over the UK’s referendum on EU membership that looks most likely to be held sometime in 2016 (any time from June onwards looks a possibility).

The hope going forward is that improved global growth and a sustained cyclical economic upturn in the Eurozone not only increasingly helps UK exports of goods and services but also lifts earnings on UK investment abroad, thereby helping the net primary income account. However, the ongoing strength of sterling against the euro is not only hampering UK exporters to the Eurozone but it dilutes the profits earned on UK investment in Eurozone countries when translated into sterling terms.

We recently spoke with SNN management prior to their quiet period. Three trends to watch into the quarter are: 1) Journey II and the unicondular knee continue to drive knee growth, pushing knees above market growth of low-single digits cc, 2) SNN continues to see opportunities from the Zimmer/Biomet (ZBH $101.73, Hold) merger, including resumes circulating around (like last quarter), but no major hiring initiatives on SNN’s part, and 3) macro conditions from China continue to result in a slowdown for SNN, which has specifically hurt sports medicine (mentioned in 3Q call) as well as trauma and wound care. Regarding takeover speculation, the company is not specifically commenting, but we continue to view a takeover as unlikely. We have tweaked our numbers for FY2015 and are adjusting our numbers for FY2016 and FY2017. Maintain Hold rating.
Discussion
Hip and Knees: SNN continues to see headwinds from the removal of smaller sized Birmingham Hip Resurfacing System (BHR) femoral heads—this drag will likely continue into 2H16. Knees continue to perform, driven by Journey II and its acquisition of ZBH’s unicondular knee (annualized revenue at $20 million). SNN continues to see opportunities as a result of the Zimmer Biomet merger and has hired sales reps, although modest.
China/EM: Management sees further weakness caused by inventory de-stocking of distributors as a result of lower demand, affecting sports medicine, trauma, and wound care.
Tweaking estimates: We are lowering our 4Q15 revenue to $1,229 million from $1,249 million and our FY15 revenue is now $4,606 million from $4,626 million. We have adjusted our FY16 and FY17 revenue estimates to $4,811 million from $4,984 million and $5,031 million from $5,389 million, respectively, and our EPS estimates to $1.77 from $1.84 and $1.93 from $2.18, respectively.
